name: C64C
sound: 3 voices / 9 octaves, 4 waveforms (sound output through TV)
ports: RGB (composite, chroma/luma and sound in/out), 2 x Joystick plugs, Cardridge slot, Tape interfarce (300 bps), Serial, User Port, TV RF output
description:
The Commodore 64C was simply the original C-64  repackaged in in a beige C-128 style case. Internally, Commodore integrated most of the hardware onto a single VLSI chip. 

The new model did not differ much from its predecessor, the only innovation was the flatter case, which made the keyboard (which had off-white keys) more ergonomic (it looked like the C128 case), not as high as than the old one. But the new case did not only have advantages: due to its low profile and additional metal screening, some of the numerous hardware expansions did not fit anymore. This was changed with the C64G.

The official name for this model was "C=64 C", but nevertheless the German 64'er magazine decided to call it "C64-II" (because the first units didn't have the new name on the label at the bottom), the badges on most of the 64 C's just says "Commodore 64". They pointed out that this name was only valid for the 64'er magazine, but since the 64'er was the magazine for the C64 for a long time, the name was widely accepted and so this model is mostly known as "C64-II" in Germany. 

Commodore took advantage of the launch of the 64C to improve its range of peripherals. The machine could be delivered with:
? the 1541C disk drive, internally the same as the previous 1541, but with a beige case,
? the 1541-II disk drive, a smaller 1541 with external power supply and a beige case
? The 1351 two-button mouse which could operate in either proportional or joystick mode,
? The 1802 color monitor which accepted both composite and RGB video signals,
? The 1764 RAM expander which plugged into the expansion port and boosted the system RAM to 256 KB.

First 64C were bundled with GEOS, developed by Berkeley Software, a good window and icon opating system, considering that it ran on a 8-bit processors and 64 KB of RAM.

Sadly, the 64C was launched at the wrong time, at a wrong price (about $80 more than the C64). At that time the competition was hard with the new Atari and Amiga 32-bit computers. The 64C thus didn't meet a large success, except in some European countries.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> RIGHT SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right:<br> Dual joystick connector, power switch and socket.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right:<br> • Cartridge slot<br> • TV chanel selector<br> • TV modulator output<br> • Audio, video DIN socket<br> • Serial DIN socket<br> • Tape recorder connector<br> • User I/O connector</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAINBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Can you help us in describing the function of each chip?</blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.mci.org.br" target="_blank">Museu da Computação e Informática - MCI</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #5 </strong></font><br><blockquote>The brochure says:<br><font color="#666666"> During Jacquard's early years, as a "system house", the company developed communications and peripheral devices that were not available from any other sources. Some of these are still available only from Jacquard. <br><br> Through these devices, Jacquard acquired hardware design and production skills, thus becoming experienced in integrating 'pieces' into systems that worked, and worked well. <br><br> These years of experience enabled Jacquard to design the first truly affordable and multi-functional small business system - the Jacquard Videocomputer... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> THINKJET ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>August 1985</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 6000 MODEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> WE HAVE A NEW APPROACH TO DISTRIBUTED PROCESSING THAT WORKS <br><br> Already implemented are electronic mail, word processing, complete cost accounting with inventory control and more. The secret is a new technology called Functionally Structured Distribution (FSD). At last, a system to organize and manage distributed processing applications that is really up and running. FSD technology is especially applicable to installa­tions that require:<br> • Unlimited expandability supporting extremely large data bases and terminals in many cities.<br> • User-friendly software easily programmed in high level languages (COBOL, FORTRAN, and BASIC)<br> • System reliability (due to distributed hardware) while maintaining multiple levels of data security.<br> • Compatibility with existing mainframes and networks (including the Bell System). <br><br> We are presently installing Billings 6000 Computer Systems which take full advantage of distributed processing utilizing FSD technology. The 6000 Computer supports multiple hard disk drives with capacities of up to 64 Mbytes (formatted), streaming tapes for backup, auto-dial modems (2400 baud synchronous) for communications, and flexible disk drives for smaller installations.</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GOLDSTAR 3DO MODEL ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://members.aol.com/djswaggle/3doad.html" target="_blank">3DO ads</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The new ASC8000-6 single board computer is packed with ultra-high technology: Z80 double density computer, up to 2048Kb of high speed RAM, Floppy-disk and Winchester Hard Disk controllers, DMA, up to 6 serial / 2 parallel I/O, optional 32 bit floating point processor... All on one board, fully socketed, fully documented, reliable and maintainable...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>''It's time''<br> ''ATMOS from Oric : the definitive computer''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"the power of words depends on the way you use them"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (SEPT. 83)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The initiator"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SAME IN GERMAN</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is nearly a stupid scan ! <br><br> The young boy says : ''In 1984, my father bought me a MO-5" <br> And on his desk is a 1998 calendar... <br><br> They meant that if you bought the MO-5 then (the advert is from 1984), you would be rich and clever 14 years later (in 1998). Ha ha ha !! <br><br> It's funny to see how they tried to represent an office and a town of 1998. I really love this one !  </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Happy family playing "La quête des anneaux" (Quest for the rings)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (JULY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil has all talents"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COCO CLONE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Sampo, a Taiwanese company specialized in monitors and video terminals production also attempted to produce a CoCo clone computer, but the marketing little lasted. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMODORE WATCHES!</strong></font><br><blockquote>While manufacturing and selling calculators in 1977, Commodore sold wristwatches.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Chuck Guzis</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

item.description: CMD SuperCPU||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CMD SUPERCPU</strong></font><br><blockquote>The SuperCPU by Creative Micro Devices is an accelerator cartridge for the Commodore 64. It contains an W65C816S processor running at 20 MHz, providing 20 times the performance of the stock 6510 processor! CMD later added a SuperRAM Card option that could include up to 16 MB of additional memory. There is also a v2 version that offers native 128 mode support (also called SuperCPU/128). It is one of the most sought-after Commodore peripherals.<p class="petitgris">Thomas Conté</p></blockquote>

CMD RAMLink||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CMD RAMLINK</strong></font><br><blockquote>This RAM expansion unit by Creative Micro Devices was intended to be used as a RAM drive to accelerate disk access. It is externally powered, and thus will preserve the data even when the computer is turned off.<p class="petitgris">Thomas Conté</p></blockquote>

Floppy disk unit 1540-1541||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> FLOPPY DISK UNIT 1540-1541</strong></font><br><blockquote>It is connected to the C64 via a serial link.<br> It is very very slow and can store 170 kb per disk.</blockquote>

Quick Data Drive||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> QUICK DATA DRIVE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>Cheaper and faster than diskettes.</b> <br><br> This Quick Data Drive from Dean Electronics is dedicated to Commodore 64 and <$252$>Vic 20</a> systems. It uses a special tape called 'Wafer', of 16, 64 or 128 Kb capacity. This wafer was also used by a product marketed for the <$223$>Sinclair Spectrum</a>, called Wafadrive. Various tests proved that the Q.D.D. was approximately 20 times faster than a normal cassette recorder and 2 or 3 times faster than the Commodore 1541 disk drive. The reason : data transfer routines (called QOS) much more efficient than those of Commodore, and a file management operating system (FMU) much more modern and powerful. <br><br> The Q.D.D. is however not more than an advanced tape recorder using a magnetic tape, and the delay to access a specific file still remains higher than with a normal disk drive. Despite its qualities, the Q.D.D. did not meet success because most C64 software was sold on disks or tapes and users had to acquire both Commodore peripherals before investing in a third powerful storage system.</blockquote>

CMD HD-20|||20Mb hard-drive|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CMD HD-20</strong></font><br><strong>> 20Mb hard-drive</strong><br><blockquote>This is a hard drive for the C64 or 128. SWAP-Devicenumber-Buttons let the HD become drive 8 or 9. It can create sub-directories and partitions, including 1541 emulation.</blockquote>
Model 1525||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MODEL 1525</strong></font><br><blockquote>It can print all the semi graphic characters of the C64. (30 characters per second)  </blockquote>
